div.p: Most magnificent Lord Heinrich of... always most esteemed...

In the past days of... letters from your lordship, very pleasing to me, to which until now I have not been able to respond due to being ill, for which reason until this past 5th of March I had sent 20 scudi, but the one who was supposed to come to Zurich did not go, so he sent the money in such a way that now I send and they are 20 scudi in good hundred here. Then to Cornelius, I ask your lordship to ensure that he writes often and not as usual, for I have received few letters from him until now, nor have I received any notice if Cornelius has received a package sent last November and the slippers and leggings. Once again, I beg you to have him write Latin letters so I can see if he has learned or not, and also write in German. For now, I write nothing more than to lower my hands to your lordship and to the most holy consort.
From Morbegno, January 27, 1572, regarding sending my sons to Zurich to be under a master, I am not sure about sending them this year.
All of your lordship's most faithful servant, Thomas Guarinoni.
To the most magnificent Lord, Lord Heinrich Bullinger... always most esteemed in Zurich.
